title: How to Freeze Ham

methods.name: Freezing Cooked Ham on the Bone

steps.headline: Dry the ham off with a paper towel or cloth.
steps.description: Though cooking takes away much of the moisture present in uncooked ham, you will still need to remove as much of what is leftover from the surface of the ham as possible. Excess moisture can cause freezer burn and toughness, which will affect the taste when you thaw and reheat it.

steps.headline: Leave the ham in the fridge for about two hours to fully cool down.
steps.description: This will further dry the ham and prepare it for being placed into frozen storage. Check back on the ham after an hour to see if it has cooled. The time the ham will take to cool will depend on various factors, like how hot it was when served, how long it sat out while you were eating, and how cold the fridge is.

steps.headline: Place the whole amount of ham into a freezer-safe bag.
steps.description: Remove as much of the air from the bag as possible. Leaving air inside the bag can cause uneven freezing or can make your ham toughen. If you have a vacuum-sealer, use it as directed to remove the air from the bag. If you do not have one, place a straw into the bag and close the bag around it; suck out all of the air through the straw, and then quickly take the straw out and close the bag.

steps.headline: Wrap the bagged ham tightly with aluminum foil and label it with the date.
steps.description: Wrapping will further protect the ham from freezer burn and preserve flavor. Cooked ham will safely last up to two months in the freezer. It’s easy to forget exactly when you put food into the freezer, especially weeks later. Writing the date in permanent marker will make sure that you stay within that time frame.

steps.headline: Clear a space in the freezer for the ham and put it in.
steps.description: The safest place to freeze meat is on the lowest shelf, where the freezer is coldest.

methods.name: Freezing Slices or Small Portions of Cooked Ham

steps.headline: Cool the ham down by placing it into the fridge for about an hour.
steps.description: Cooling makes the ham easier to work with and also helps to remove excess moisture from the surface.

steps.headline: Cut the ham into smaller portions if you have not already done so.
steps.description: Using a sharp knife, slice or chop and dice the ham. The pieces can be as large or small you like, but should be relatively uniform in size. Keeping pieces roughly the same size ensures that the ham freezes and will thaw evenly.

steps.headline: Separate the slices or pieces into serving sizes.
steps.description: On a large plate, make several groupings of single servings of the ham. A single serving of ham is 3 ounces (85 g), which is roughly the same weight as a deck of cards. Serving sizes can also be generally measured as being the same size as the palm of your hand as well, though this might be harder to use as a guide for slices of ham.

steps.headline: Place individual portions of the ham into freezer-safe bags.
steps.description: Each bag should contain an amount that you will be comfortable with defrosting and eating completely, since you will not want to refreeze the ham once it has thawed. For example, if you would like to eat two servings of ham for dinner, place two servings into the bag. Depending on how large you want your portions to be, you may need bags that are gallon-sized, quart-sized, sandwich-sized, or a combination of the three.

steps.headline: Remove as much air from the bag as you can.
steps.description: This can be done most effectively with a vacuum sealer. If you do not own one, you can remove most of the air by placing a straw into the bag, closing the seal around the straw and then sucking the air out; once most of the air has been sucked out, quickly pull the straw out and seal the bag shut.

steps.headline: Wrap the individual portion bags with aluminum foil and write the date on each.
steps.description: Aluminum foil adds an extra layer of protection from freezer burn. The ham will last up to two months safely in the freezer.

steps.headline: Put the aluminum foil-wrapped bags of ham into the freezer.
steps.description: Make sure to let them completely freeze before defrosting. This should take a day at most, though this length of time is affected by how cold you keep your freezer.

steps.headline: Keep uncooked ham portions in their original packaging.
steps.description: If you buy a whole ham or portions of a ham from the store and do not plan on cooking them relatively soon, you can simply put them into the freezer as long as the original packaging has not been broken. If the original packaging opens, you will have to further wrap the ham to protect it from contamination and freezer burn.

steps.headline: Bag opened, uncooked ham portions based on serving size.
steps.description: Place the uncooked ham into bags so that you only need to defrost as much as you can finish at a time, or into a large bag if it is a whole ham.

steps.headline: Wrap the bags of uncooked ham with aluminum foil and write the date on them.
steps.description: Wrapping in foil reduces the chances of your ham getting freezer burn and further preserves the taste. Knowing what date you placed the bags into the freezer will let you know how long they have been in the freezer for. Uncooked ham can stay in the freezer for approximately 4 months.

steps.headline: Clear a space in the freezer and put the ham in.
steps.description: Let the ham freeze completely before beginning to defrost it; this should take no longer than a day.
